meta.title: A Border Story: The Thai-Cambodian Conflict
meta.subtitle: English Lesson

slides.title: A BORDER STORY
slides.subtitle: Inside the Thai-Cambodian Conflict
slides.notes: Welcome the class. Ask students if they like stories about history or news. Introduce the 'Border Story' as a real event in their region.

slides.title: What's going on?
slides.content:
• Look at the temple. What do you know about the Thai-Cambodian border?
  • Have you ever heard of the Preah Vihear Temple? Why is there a fight here?
  • What does it mean to 'flee'? Why would families do this?
slides.notes: Elicit what students already know about Preah Vihear. If they are unsure, explain it is a beautiful ancient temple that both countries claim. Use the picture of the soldiers to set a serious but curious tone.

slides.title: Power Words
slides.notes: Transition slide. Tell students: 'Before we watch the news, we need some Power Words to help us understand the story.'

slides.title: Learning 'Power Words'
slides.content:
üß≠ When words are difficult, don't worry! Here is the plan:

  • üé≠ Check the vibe: Does the word seem happy or scary?
  • üáπüá≠ Think in Thai: Find a word in Thai that feels the same.
  • üó£Ô∏è Speak it: Let's practice saying them together!
slides.notes: Explain the strategy. TEACHER TIP: Matching words is like a puzzle. Once you finish, you can use them to talk about the real world! Emphasize that 'Thinking in Thai' is a useful tool.

slides.definition: To make something less serious or painful.
slides.example: Let's try to mitigate the problem by talking peacefully.
slides.notes: Drill pronunciation. CCQ: 'If a doctor gives you medicine for a headache, is he mitigating the pain?' (Yes).

slides.definition: To hit back after being attacked.
slides.example: If someone hits you, do you retaliate or stay calm?
slides.notes: Drill pronunciation. This is a key word for the conflict. Ask: 'Is retaliating usually a good way to stay peaceful?' (No).

slides.definition: A promise to stop fighting for a while.
slides.example: A campfire is warm; a ceasefire is peaceful.
slides.notes: Drill pronunciation. Explain that 'cease' means 'stop'.

slides.definition: To move people away from danger to a safe place.
slides.example: During the flood, many families had to evacuate their homes.
slides.notes: Drill pronunciation. Ask students if they have ever seen an evacuation (fire drill or flood).

slides.definition: Irritable and always wanting to argue.
slides.example: When brothers and sisters are tired, they become fractious!
slides.notes: Drill pronunciation. This describes the relationship between the two sides in the report.

slides.title: Power Match

pairs.def: Move people to a safe place.

shuffled.def: Move people to a safe place.

slides.notes: Give students 2 minutes to match the words on their worksheets. Walk around and help.

slides.title: Power Match: Answers

pairs.def: Move people to a safe place.

slides.notes: Confirm answers. Use auto-animate to show the definitions moving into place. Praise correct matches!

slides.title: The Field Report
slides.notes: Transition: 'Now we are going to watch the actual BBC Field Report. Be ready to use your ears and your eyes!'

slides.title: The Big Picture
slides.content:
üì∫ When we watch the news, we don't need to understand everything.

  • üòü Watch faces: Are they happy or scared?
  • üéôÔ∏è Listen for tone: Is the reporter excited or calm?
  • üì∞ What is the topic? What is the main story?
slides.notes: Help students feel confident. PRO TIP: If you see smoke or running people, you already know the story is about conflict! Remind them that understanding the 'vibe' is a real world listening skill.

slides.title: The Situation Today
questions: Is it getting better or worse?
slides.notes: Play the video. Monitor student reactions. If the video is too fast, you can play it twice.

slides.title: What did we see?
slides.transcript_snippet: This confrontation is one of the most severe since the ceasefire back in July.
slides.explanation: The reporter highlights that violence is increasing and more families are fleeing than before.
slides.notes: Confirm the gist. Ask for one or two reasons why they think it's getting worse (e.g. 'soldiers', 'crying people').

slides.title: Mission Directive: Task 3
slides.content:
‚öîÔ∏è Now look at Task 3. We are splitting the mission roles:

  • üë§ B1 Agents: You'll be listening for the Human Impact (how it affects people).
  • üèõÔ∏è B2 Agents: You'll be listening for the Diplomatic Friction (the blame game).
slides.notes: Direct students to their specific tasks. B1 focuses on families/schools; B2 focuses on accusations and claims.

slides.title: Listening for Detail
slides.content:
üìù How to capture intelligence effectively:

  • üîë Identify Keywords: Listen for specific nouns (shelters, air force, targets).
  • üë§ Identify Sources: Note who is making the claim (Thai side vs. Cambodian side).
  • ‚úçÔ∏è Quick Notes: Use symbols or 1-word hints. Don't write full sentences yet!
slides.notes: Give students a moment to prepare their notebooks. Advise them to only listen for their assigned facts.

slides.title: Fact-Finding
slides.content:
B1: Families

Find 3 ways the conflict hurts ordinary families.

B2: The Blame Game

Who said: 'Targeting military sites'? Who Denied starting the fight?
slides.notes: Set the timer. Walk around and help students identify the specific claims from the reporter.

slides.title: B1 Facts: Families
slides.transcript_snippet: A lot of people have moved to shelters... Schools have been shut, meaning students cannot go to school on either side.
slides.explanation: The clip confirms the humanitarian impact on civilians and the disruption of local education.
slides.notes: Discuss how these feel to a student (especially the 'No school' part - would they like that or would it be scary?).

slides.title: B2 Facts: The Blame Game
slides.transcript_snippet: Thailand's air force said it struck Cambodian military targets... Cambodia has denied provoking violence.
slides.explanation: Both governments use specific language to justify their actions or deny fault.
slides.notes: Highlight the 'Blame Game'. Ask: 'In a fight, does anyone ever say they started it?' (Rarely).

slides.title: Reaching Peace
slides.notes: Transition: 'Now, you are the leaders. Can you solve this problem?'

slides.title: Reaching a Deal
slides.content:
ü§ù A good leader is kind but firm.

  • üïäÔ∏è Soft phrases: 'We think we should...'
  • üè´ Be a helper: 'How can we help the schools?'
  • üåà Future thinking: 'Let's stop the fear.'
slides.notes: Model some soft language. THE WIN: A good solution makes the fighting stop! Encourage them to use the Power Words like 'mitigate' and 'ceasefire' during the task.

slides.title: Peace Deal
slides.content:
Group A: Helping People

Create a 3-step plan (Food, Doctors, Schools).

Group B: The Rules

Create 3 rules for peace (Meetings, No blame, Observors).
slides.notes: Monitor closely. This is the heart of the lesson. Encourage students to talk to each other and compromise.

slides.title: Peace at last!
slides.subtitle: You worked hard as a team.
slides.notes: Final wrap up. Praise their diplomatic skills. Tell them they have learned how to look at complex news stories as global citizens.
